pullRequest.body:
Prove `n.choose k ~ n^k / k!` and `n.choose k = Θ(n^k)` as `n → ∞`.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

This is needed for a proof of the Erdős-Stone-Simonovits theorem for simple graphs.

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body: Don't forget to remove the awaiting-author label when you're done.
This is good work, thanks! I made some suggestions, don't hesitate if you have questions.
This is good work, thanks! I made some suggestions, don't hesitate if you have questions.

You can also open `Filter` and `Nat` to avoid prefix, e.g. write `atTop` instead of `Filter.atTop`.
```suggestion
open Asymptotics Filter Nat Topology
```

You can put the statement on one line, it's more readable I think. Also, some type ascriptions are not needed because the types are inferred from the context. Feel free to leave them if you think it's more readable though. Same comment for the two other statements below.
```suggestion
lemma isEquivalent_descFactorial (k : ℕ) :
    (fun n ↦ (n.descFactorial k : ℝ)) ~[Filter.atTop] (fun (n : ℕ) ↦ n^k) := by
```
I can't remove *all* the type ascriptions, and don't like leaving just *some* ascriptions.

You can do this in one line like this.
```suggestion
      exact ⟨1, fun n hn ↦ ne_of_gt (mod_cast hn)⟩
```
In fact the whole block can be done in one line with
`Filter.eventually_atTop.2 ⟨1, fun n hn ↦ ne_of_gt (mod_cast hn)⟩`. Chose the option you prefer.

Here you can do
```suggestion
  simp_rw [div_eq_mul_inv, mul_comm _ (_⁻¹)]
```
It requires to specify the argument to `mul_comm` (just saying it's the inverse of something works fine) but it avoids the conv bloc.

When you apply a lemma and you leave some argument as `_` to be proven later, it's more readable to use the tactic `refine` instead. It allows you to write the skeleton of the proof, and in the place of the arguments that you will prove later you can put `?_`, and `refine` will create a goal for it. That way we don't mess between implicit argument automatically inferred represented as `_` and arguments provided later represented as `?_`.
```suggestion
    refine IsEquivalent.mul ?_ h
```

You can merge those two lines in one if you want. If you prefer to leave it like this because it is more readable, you might want to use `refine` instead of `apply` for the same reason as before. Also, you can use dot notation to write `isTheta_rfl.const_mul_left`, which is the same as `IsTheta.const_mul_left ?_ isTheta_rfl` but the argument of type `IsTheta` replaces the namespace. This allows for more compact and easier to read expressions.
```suggestion
  exact isTheta_rfl.const_mul_left (inv_ne_zero (mod_cast k.factorial_ne_zero))
```

pullRequest.title: feat(Analysis/SpecialFunctions): prove asymptotic results for binomial coefficents and factorial variants

nodes.body: This is good work, thanks! I made some suggestions, don't hesitate if you have questions.
Don't forget to remove the awaiting-author label when you're done.
